IRM 11.3.31.1 - Revised the title to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
a. IRM
, Background - Added background information on the Tax Checks Reports on Federal Appointees process. The ﬁrst four paragraphs of the prior IRM
, General incorporated into this section. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities governing disclosures of Tax Checks Reports on Federal Appointees. Information from the prior IRM
, General, (
) and (
), were incorporated into this section. c. IRM

d. IRM
, Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used abbreviations and their deﬁnitions regarding disclosures of Tax Checks Reports on Federal Appointees.

Removed all of (3) from IRM 11.3.31.3 since Criminal Investigation will no longer be performing notiﬁcation. Removed sentence in (4) stating that non White House request referrals will be made Director, Collection Policy. Also added reference to IRM 5.1.8.5.2 in (4).
This supersedes IRM 11.3.31 dated May 20, 2015.

on Federal Appointees

) Purpose: This IRM section provides instructions concerning disclosures of information in Tax Checks Reports for Federal Appointees. Federal and other governmental entities periodically perform background on prospective employees. These investigations often include a request to to perform a tax check. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (
) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the vicewide Disclosure policy. (

) Federal agencies, the White House, Executive Office of the President, and other governmental entities periodically perform background investigations prospective employees, contractors, certain award nominees, and others to advance their mission. These investigations may include a federal Tax Agencies will request a Tax Check report to supplement investigations con- cerning character, loyalty, or suitability of such prospective appointees, employees, contractors or award nominees. This may include positions of sensitive nature or that require high level clearances. (

) Examples of the types of positions that require a Tax Check are: a. Prospective Presidential appointees that require Senate conﬁrmation b. Nominees for Presidential “E” Awards established by Executive Order
c. Candidates for the Malcolm Baldrige Award d. Certain other persons/entities Note: Other consent programs based on IRC §
(c) for delivery of account scripts are routinely handled by other locally established procedures. See IRM
, Disclosure to Designees and Practitioners. (
) The IRS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) function responsible for conducting these tax checks and issuing a report to the re- questing agency. (

) There are three types of Tax Check cases - routine, priority and extreme priority. a. Routine cases are assigned to the ﬁeld Disclosure offices based on inventory needs and are to be processed within
days of receipt. b. Priority cases are also assigned to a ﬁeld Disclosure office but are to processed within

days of receipt. c. Extreme priority cases are generally tax checks for White House tees. These Tax Checks cases are assigned to a specialized team speciﬁc Disclosure Office and are to be processed within
days of receipt. (
) Tax Check requests for tax information are made pursuant to:
Tax Check Reports on Federal Appointees
Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy.
a. Routine cases are assigned to the ﬁeld Disclosure offices based on inventory needs and are to be processed within
days of receipt. b. Priority cases are also assigned to a ﬁeld Disclosure office but are to be processed within

days of receipt. c. Extreme priority cases are generally tax checks for White House appoin- tees. These Tax Checks cases are assigned to a specialized team within a speciﬁc Disclosure Office and are to be processed within
days of

) based on Department of the Treasury’s tax responsibility to ensure current and prospective employees and tors are compliant with their tax obligations. These Tax Checks are conducted within the Human Capitol and Chief Financial Offices (

Due to the sensitivity or high proﬁle nature of some Tax Check cases, delegated authority to sign certain responses may supersede Delegation Order
, found in IRM

For example, Tax Check reports on White House requests with adverse ﬁndings require sioner Office review and approval and are signed by the Disclosure Deputy Associate Director, East or West. Note: Requests for tax compliance checks not described above are worked through routine agency procedures, i.e. mortgage loan requests, state licensing, etc. Disclosure offices should refer requesters to the Transcript Delivery System (TDS) or the campus Return and Income Veriﬁcation Service (RAIVS) units who are established to handle this type of work. Note: Disclosures of federal tax information to Probation Officers for taxpayers tax related convictions are typically handled by the Criminal Investigation function based on IRC §
) This IRM is used by all IRS employees to comply with the provisions of §
(c) pertaining to disclosures of Tax Check Reports for Federal tees. (

Requests for tax compliance checks not described above are worked through routine agency procedures, i.e. mortgage loan requests, state licensing, etc. Disclosure offices should refer requesters to the Transcript Delivery System (TDS) or the campus Return and Income Veriﬁcation Service (RAIVS) units who are established to handle this type of work.
The following is a list of the acronyms that are used in this IRM section:
Reports on Federal Appointees
Acronym Deﬁnition PGLD Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure RAIVS Return and Income Veriﬁcation Service RO Revenue Officer TDS Transcript Delivery System (

) Generally a Tax Check Report provides the following information to the requester for the years speciﬁed in the waiver: in a. Whether the individual has ﬁled federal income tax returns as required? b. Whether the individual has failed to pay any tax, penalties, and interest within a speciﬁed period after notice and demand? Note: The requesting agency will determine the number of years and scope of Tax Check request. Each agency will state what constitutes “timely” ﬁling payment in the consent, which may be different from the standards estab- lished for IRS employees tax compliance. Reading the consent is critical ensure the response provides only the years and information that is autho- rized. Determination of timeliness is based on the consent language. (

) The Disclosure employee must review the waiver for validity. A valid waiver must: • Be signed by the taxpayer. Electronic signatures are not acceptable. • Have a handwritten date and be received by the IRS within

days the date the taxpayer signed the waiver. • Name an authorized individual to receive the information. A listing of authorized individuals can be found on the Disclosure Share Point • Contain at least two of these three elements: Taxpayer’s Name, er’s Address or Taxpayer’s Social Security Number. (
) If our response to any of the above questions in (

) above is yes then we provide speciﬁc details explaining the adverse determination ONLY if the waiver authorizes that disclosure. If the consent does not authorize the of detailed information, we can only provide Yes/No responses. (
) The caseworker initiates requests for information needed to prepare Tax Reports. for (

) Tax Check Transcripts and/or complete transcripts of account are requested from TDS and/or through IDRS. The assigned caseworker will conduct research to gather sufficient information to respond to the request. A Tax Check response is a status report on the taxpayer’s compliance concerning federal tax ﬁling and payment. Additional information on research techniques and the correct preparation of responses can be found in the Tax Check cessing Guides on the Disclosure Share Point site. (
) If the data secured in IRM
)a), shows no record of ﬁling for any all of the years covered by the waiver and additional research indicates a (

If the data secured in IRM 11.3.31.2 (1)a), shows no record of ﬁling for any or all of the years covered by the waiver and additional research indicates a ﬁling
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

requirement or an outstanding balance, White House, Executive Office of the President (EOP) and Department of Justice (DOJ) requests only will be forwarded to the Director, Collection Policy (HQ) for immediate assignment to Revenue Officer (RO). (See IRM

, Tax Checks on Political and Government Employees.) These DOJ requests are normally political ap- pointments and handled differently than other requests from DOJ. The DOJ, White House, and EOP requests require that the RO contact the taxpayer within

hours of receipt. The tax check case will remain open until the is secured or all efforts to secure the return have been exhausted. In the meantime, an interim response is sent to the White House, EOP or DOJ to advise that we are attempting to contact the taxpayer to determine if a return(s) was ﬁled or to secure the non-ﬁled return(s). This will close the Tax Check case. (

) If the taxpayer indicates that the return was ﬁled, the RO must secure proof ﬁling such as a canceled check matching the balance due per the taxpayer’s retained copy of the return. In the event that the original canceled check cannot be located, a copy must be secured. If such proof is not obtainable, in the case of a refund return, a copy of the tax return must be secured by RO for transmission as a “possible duplicate return” to the appropriate Campus based on the taxpayer’s address. Note: In failure to ﬁle cases, returns should not be solicited without consideration for Criminal Investigation implications. (

) If the RO ﬁnds that the return has not been ﬁled, he/she should ascertain whether a return was required to be ﬁled. If a return should have been ﬁled, the RO must secure the return. Note: No summons should be issued without ﬁrst contacting the Collection nator. (

) If the taxpayer is uncooperative (e.g., fails to respond to calls, fails to meet pointments, and fails to provide documents), that fact along with pertinent details are reported to the Disclosure caseworker. They will make contact the requesting agency to help secure additional taxpayer cooperation. The caseworker will notify the RO of any additional information obtained from the requesting agency concerning further attempts to contact the taxpayer. (

) Taxpayers are to be advised not to mail delinquent returns to the campuses for processing. Such actions will delay veriﬁcation of ﬁling. Returns are not to be sent to the Disclosure Office as this action will also delay processing of original or “possible duplicate return” by the Campus. See (
) above. (
) The results of the taxpayer contact will be reported to the caseworker by secure e-mail. (
) The caseworker will prepare a Tax Check report after the receipt and analysis of all relevant return and return information. (
) The Tax Check Report will consist of a response for each item listed on the waiver. (
) Tax Check Reports are either mailed or faxed to the requester based on dures established with each requester. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

hours of receipt. The tax check case will remain open until the return is secured or all efforts to secure the return have been exhausted. In the meantime, an interim response is sent to the White House, EOP or DOJ to advise that we are attempting to contact the taxpayer to determine if a return(s) was ﬁled or to secure the non-ﬁled return(s). This will close the Tax Check case. (

) If the taxpayer indicates that the return was ﬁled, the RO must secure proof of ﬁling such as a canceled check matching the balance due per the taxpayer’s retained copy of the return. In the event that the original canceled check cannot be located, a copy must be secured. If such proof is not obtainable, as in the case of a refund return, a copy of the tax return must be secured by the RO for transmission as a “possible duplicate return” to the appropriate Campus based on the taxpayer’s address.

nator. (

) If the taxpayer is uncooperative (e.g., fails to respond to calls, fails to meet ap- pointments, and fails to provide documents), that fact along with pertinent details are reported to the Disclosure caseworker. They will make contact with the requesting agency to help secure additional taxpayer cooperation. The caseworker will notify the RO of any additional information obtained from the requesting agency concerning further attempts to contact the taxpayer. (

) Taxpayers are to be advised not to mail delinquent returns to the campuses for processing. Such actions will delay veriﬁcation of ﬁling. Returns are not to be sent to the Disclosure Office as this action will also delay processing of the original or “possible duplicate return” by the Campus. See (
) above. (
) The results of the taxpayer contact will be reported to the caseworker by secure e-mail. (

) The caseworker will prepare a Tax Check report after the receipt and analysis of all relevant return and return information. The Tax Check Report will consist of a response for each item listed on the waiver. Tax Check Reports are either mailed or faxed to the requester based on proce- dures established with each requester.
